This past week I was allowed to present my honors research at the Western Institute Of Nursing Conference in Salt Lake City, Utah. This research conference focuses on connecting a community of nurses and improving health through nursing research, education, and practices with this year focusing on health, equity, changing health, and climates. My honors thesis research focuses on the relationship between perceived stress and food insecurity within the NIH All of Us database. I also got to work on a team of 6 students and 2 faculty mentors to present the first Planetary Health Report Card for WSU College of Nursing . I am honored to attend this conference and present my research for the first time. Thank you Washington State University - Honors College and the American Association of Colleges of Nursing (AACN) for your support.

The 2nd Muslim CEOs Dinner Series in London this month, took place last night. The event, a joint initiative supported by Elipses and the Riba Free Foundation , brings together Muslim CEOs and Founders to share business insights and experience, guided by faith. 34 founders and CEOs were in attendance last night. Here are the key themes of the evening that resonated with me were: 💰 Riba: there was a strong Islamic finance attendance and it was a universal view that businesses should be built free of riba if we are to solve the world's problems in a meaningful way. Moreover financial services has a duty to provide non riba based solutions to the wider economy. 🤝 Community: Almost everyone had a story about finding their tribe within the Muslim community after being disillusioned in their career or gaining a wealth of support from their community when starting out and seeking advice. Lots of great connections made to further bring together our community last night, Alhumdullilah. ❤️ The Giving Economy: Charity is the beating heart of the Muslim community. Muslims donate 4x more than non Muslims to charity in the UK. Our guest speaker, Nobel prize nominee Dr. Amjad Saqib , founder of Akhuwat is a living embodiment of building business with impact and that the responsibility lies with all of us to give back in any way we can during our careers. As always thanks to my co-organiser Omar Khaliel without whose tireless efforts these events couldn't come together and to his team at RFF. This was our last event of the year. We'll be back in January with our next event in Birmingham (which I'm reliably told will be epic - no pressure Zhagum Arshad ). If you are a Muslim founder/CEO, join the LinkedIn group to hear about our next event and other events in 2025. LinkedIn Group: https://lnkd.in/eeQGHFVN Aatif Khan Ahmad El Nashar Ali Siddiqui Ali Zafar Areeb Siddiqui Arif Anis FRSA Aysha H Ingar Azhar Hameed Deena Ataie Fawaad B. Hussain Muhamed Mushtaq Rehman Nabeel Khan Naseem Ahmed Nomaan Aleem Mufti Omar DaCosta-Shahid Rami Saadi Salma K. Shuaib Hussain Shjeel Ahmed Siddique Esmail Sulaiman Ahmed Syed Saif ur rehman Shah Tarek El Diwany Tohid Ismail Umar Ahmed Waqas Iqbal Syed Zain Abbas Ahmed Junaid,CCDE, Zeeshan Aftab

One of the pause practices my partner Rena Satre Meloy (she.her) and I really appreciate at the end of the work week is a reflection we call The Triple Dub: "WHAT WENT WELL?" Pause. Relax your body. Take a deep breath. And ask yourself – WHAT WENT WELL? Give yourself some space to really soak in the good. Just to be clear: this is NOT about avoiding or disregarding challenges. There's a LOT that's difficult right now – for everyone – both personally and professionally. This practice is about resourcing yourself. It's about creating space to allow the things that ARE going well to shift to the foreground, so that they can support you in effectively taking on the challenges ahead. You can carve out 60 seconds for this or invite your whole team to join you in making space to soak in the good. Ending the week focusing on your wins (big or small) boosts morale, counterbalances the brain’s negativity bias, and invites a sense of ease and accomplishment going into the weekend. #pauseatwork #mindfulnessatwork #mindfulleadership #resilienceatwork #resilience

In the wake of Hurricanes Helene and Milton, Howmet Aerospace , and the Howmet Aerospace Foundation stand united in support of those impacted by these devastating storms. We are proud to announce that the Howmet Aerospace Foundation is issuing two separate grants of $100,000 each to the American Red Cross . The first grant will be used for relief efforts in the aftermath of Hurricane Helene, which has impacted areas near Savannah, Georgia and Morristown, Tennessee, where some Howmet employees reside. The second grant of $100,000 is being issued to provide support for the relief efforts from Hurricane Milton. Thank you to all the individuals and organizations working tirelessly on the ground to help those in need in the Southeast.

'Qatar is the Muslim Wakanda' my daughter said 🤗 … And she may just be right. After spending an incredible week in Doha, it’s hard to disagree. This city, and the vision behind it, is nothing short of extraordinary. New friendships, inspiring conversations, and a global network of changemakers, it really felt like stepping into the future. Here’s what struck me most, their ability to dream without limits. Anything they can imagine, they seem to build. For someone like me, who’s always worked within tight, riba-free budgets and self-funded ventures, this level of ambition realisation is awe-inspiring. A few standout places: Education City They didn’t just send students abroad, they brought entire universities to Qatar. American institutions with world-class faculty housed in state-of-the-art facilities. Learning spaces so beautiful, they make you want to stay forever. Minaretein Centre A stunning fusion of purpose—half mosque, half university. It’s a space for education, spirituality, and growth. Hosting global speakers, workshops, and lectures, it’s a perfect model of what learning and faith combined can achieve. Qatar National Library An architectural masterpiece. Event spaces, exhibitions, cafés, and workspaces all rolled into one. It’s unlike anything I’ve ever seen in the UK, a hub for ideas and innovation. Al-Mujadilah Center and Mosque for Women A dedicated space for women, empowering discussions, workshops, and personal development. A true testament to fostering progress through inclusivity. Qatar Science & Technology Park (QSTP) AI, advanced research, and cutting-edge innovation, QSTP is where the future is being built. Outdoor lecture theatres, exhibition spaces, and global events set the stage for trailblazing developments. Qatar has done all this in just 20 years. Let that sink in. They’ve taken their energy revenues and invested in people, ideas, and an equitable future for humanity. They are building a nation that incubates venture builders, dreamers, and change-makers. This isn’t just progress it’s perhaps what leadership for the benefit of your people looks like. Qatar really is one to watch, and I can’t wait to see what the next 20 years bring. Grateful to all the amazing folks at Qatar Foundation for the hospitality, brotherhood, and vision we experienced during the GMW Network Summit leaving me inspired. Heading into the New Year, I’m reminded that the only limits are the ones we place on ourselves. I am ready to dream and build bigger Inshaa’Allah. #GMWSummit #Qatar #qatarfoundation

Excited to share our newest publication: What 1,000 Farmers Told Us About Tech Adoption Farmers can be cautious adopters of new technology - and understandably, because who wants to literally 'bet the farm' on something new? As the agriculture industry explores ways to accelerate technology adoption we must put farmers at the center of the conversation and really understand their needs and priorities. In this article, we share insights from a survey of 1,000 US farmers that reveal key motivators behind their technology purchase decisions. We used BCG's proprietary Demand Centric Growth approach - which is often applied in Consumer Products - to get a nuanced understanding of what farmers really need. What we see is a clear need to understand not only functional needs - such as reliability and ROI - but also emotional needs - such as helping farmers feel in control, and to feel like good stewards of the soil. By applying new lenses to existing challenges, we can find innovative approaches and meaningful opportunities. Thanks to my colleagues Emily Kos , David Potere Hillary Child and Helena Conant for conducting this research! Check out the full article for more insights...

Q3 was a game-changing quarter with $142M in revenue (19% growth YoY) and $55.8M in gross profit (21% growth YoY). This strong performance highlights the effectiveness of our operations, particularly in Marketplace growth, where we saw a 24% increase YoY. 📈 We’ve been executing on a global scale, with international revenue up 55%, now making up 16% of our total revenue. Our marketplace is expanding fast, reaching 4,200+ suppliers, and we’re seeing 24% more active buyers compared to last year. 🌍 Our operational strategy of automating processes, improving backend systems, and expanding our supplier base has been key to this success. These efforts allow us to offer a seamless experience for both buyers and suppliers, enhancing value across the board. 🤝 As we wrap up the year, we’ll continue to focus on scaling operations, driving deeper engagement with enterprise customers, and enhancing our marketplace offerings. Big things ahead as we head into 2025! 🚀 #OperationalExcellence #GlobalExpansion #MarketplaceGrowth #TeamSuccess

I am absolutely thrilled to work with my new team; however, without my team members in Emerging Technology, I would not have had the experience needed to face this new challenge.These individuals taught me the ropes of a hands-on, techncial position that was out of my comfort zone with nothing but patience, grace, and of course, great senses of humor. Through my time spent in ET, I was able to gain a better understanding of daily business operations, learn the functionality of our products, develop new skill sets, and travel to places I had never been. Lastly, I began establishing 1:1 relationships with our customers, technicians, and dealers. I'm extremely excited to build upon these relationships through the Customer Experience Coordinator position. Cheers to this next chapter at HYMH! Always incredibly thankful for the culture of growth and opportunity that l've experienced over the past few years. Couldn't help but take a trip down memory lane, reminiscing on some fun memories over the past year with some incredible people💛

Behind every smile at work, there's a story. Here's mine: See the guy in the photo? This is me, circa 2006. Most people who knew me then would have probably described me as outgoing, easygoing, carefree, always smiling. But inside? I was suffocating with anxiety. Every interaction felt like a minefield of self-doubt. The game-changer? Learning to pause and observe my thoughts without judgment. I realized my anxiety wasn't a life sentence – it was a pattern I could change. Not everyone battles social anxiety, but we all have our struggles. Maybe it's imposter syndrome, perfectionism, or difficulty setting boundaries. Whatever your challenge, this journey from inner turmoil to emotional intelligence is possible for all of us. It's not about eliminating stress or 'fixing' ourselves. It's about AWARENESS. And training our minds to see what's actually happening (internally and externally) instead of the habitual stories we tell ourselves. Most of all, it's about self-compassion – treating ourselves with the same kindness we'd offer a friend or colleague. By learning to pause and observe our thoughts and feelings with openness, we can break free from patterns that hold us back. Imagine leading your team not just with strategic brilliance but with emotional mastery. That's the kind of leadership that transforms organizations from the inside out. Ready to take the first step? Try this: Next time you feel overwhelmed, pause for 60 seconds. • Take some conscious deep breaths to find some sense of grounding. • Next, observe your thoughts without trying to change them. • Label them in your mind – planning, worrying, judging, problem-solving, self-criticizing, comparing, doubting, anticipating, etc. You might be surprised by the clarity that emerges. What's your biggest challenge in managing emotions at work? #EmotionalIntelligence #AuthenticLeadership #WorkplaceWellness #PowerofPause

I was honored to speak to the Back-to-Back Nebraska Class A State Champion Westside Warriors football team last Thursday night! When I first met head coach Paul Limongi a few weeks ago I immediately witnessed what makes his teams so special... Whether it's sports or business, everyone talks about the importance of "culture," but so often it's just that, TALK. Not. At. Westside. Coach Limongi LIVES and BREATHES it! The players are educated and understand, with absolute clarity the following: Westside Football's ✔ Mission ✔ Vision ✔ Values I was amazed at how locked in these players were. They know the roadmap because they're lead by a coach who does not equivocate on what it takes! I went to Westside to give a motivational speech, but left wanting to strap on a helmet and play one more game!!!! Can't wait to see what's in store for this group in 2024! #EPICJourney #Motivationalspeaking #Football #Highschoolfootball Westside High School Larry Widman Nate LeGrand, CFP®

Just wrapped up the Gallup Strengths assessment and found out my top strengths: Ideation, Includer, Woo, Strategic, and Developer! It’s pretty exciting to dig into what drives me and how I can use these strengths day-to-day. I’m especially pumped about how these traits match up with my love for creative problem-solving, building strong relationships, leading with purpose, and helping others grow! One of the best parts about working at Mutual of Omaha is how much the company invests in our personal growth! Getting to do this assessment as a perk is just one example. Plus, next week I get to dive even deeper into these strengths in a class, and I’m really looking forward to seeing how I can keep leveling up and making an impact. If we’ve worked together, I’d love to know—do you think these strengths sound like me? And for those who’ve taken the assessment, what positive shifts have you noticed after learning about your own strengths? #MutualofOmaha #StrengthsFinder #PersonalGrowth #Leadership #CareerJourney #Grateful #TeamSpirit

🇶🇦Doha’s AI Week: A Glimpse into the Future ⭕️ Today, I spent the day at the the AI Week event at QSTP in Doha, and it was nothing short of eye-opening. Qatar is making bold moves to position itself as a global hub for tech innovation. From robotics to HealthTech and governance, the focus on applied AI is unmatched. The energy and enthusiasm for what’s next in tech is tangible—something I haven’t felt in the UK for a long time. What really stood out? The intentionality. Qatar is putting its money where its mouth is: - Cutting government red tape to make life easier for startups. - Building state-of-the-art venues and infrastructure. - Committing significant investment to incubate talent from all corners of the world. And let’s not ignore the lifestyle factors. With low crime rates, great weather, modern facilities, and a safe environment, Qatar is becoming an attractive destination for the world’s top talent. The Middle East isn’t just catching up anymore it’s pulling ahead! This leaves me with one key concern for the UK. While we’re caught up in bureaucracy and navigating endless hurdles for startups, regions like Qatar are rolling out the red carpet for innovators. They’ve got the funding, the vision, and the willingness to make things happen. The competition for talent is going global, and the UK risks being left behind unless we act now to foster a more supportive and enabling environment for startups. The future is being built. The question is—will we be part of it, or left watching from the sidelines? #AIInnovation #Qatar #StartupCulture #FutureOfTech

This past weekend, I had the great opportunity to lead a team of passionate students from the University at Buffalo ’s student club, the Association of General Contractors, in the ASC Region 1 Design-Build Competition hosted by Skanska . This was my third ASC competition, and it is always a meaningful experience to connect with the construction industry and learn from the experienced individuals who play key roles in building our country! First, I want to congratulate my team for all their hard work this weekend. Coming from an engineering background and competing head-to-head with an experienced mix of construction and architecture majors requires immense grit and adaptability. Although we fell short of our goal of reaching the podium, I am proud of the effort everyone put in. I am confident that this experience will lead to great improvements and contribute to success in future competitions. Second, I want to thank the Skanska judging team for puting together a challenging and well-structured problem. It was one of the most diverse and complex problems I have tackled in this competition, and I’m sure every participating student will become a better professional because of this experience. Lastly, special thanks to UBuffalo Civil, Structural and Environmental Engineering and Brendan Manning for all the continious support to our club. As well as thanks to all the ASC Region 1 coordinators for organizing a fantastic conference and competition. I’m looking forward to participating in the coming ASC Region 6 & 7 competition in Reno, Nevada! #ASCRegion1 #DesignBuildCompetition #skanska

The Manufacturing Process of TPE Car Mats TPE car mats are made from a thermoplastic elastomer (TPE) material👇 👉 The manufacturing process of TPE car mats begins with the raw TPE material, 👉 The TPE is melted and then mixed with a colorant and other additives, 👉 The mixture is then poured into a mold, where it is cooled and solidified. Viktor Nagy Rastko Litricin Marcus Scholle Stay up to date with me 🛎️💥👉 Miloš Kučera 🛎️ Activate Bell for all posts 🌃Join to 58.000+ followers on my #LinkedIn #carmats #plasticmanufacturing #automation

A days work can take you to some spectacular places…just spent an amazing day at Cape Kidnappers Golf Course in Hawke’s Bay New Zealand. Neil Tombs from Brandt recently delivered a Wiedenmann XD8 Terra Spike deep tine aerator from Fieldquip Ag and Turf for maintenance of this outstanding golf course. The golf course and adjacent resort, Rosewood Cape Kidnappers occupy a 6000-acre working sheep and cattle station, adding a unique charm and natural beauty to the area. Perched atop rolling hills and rugged cliffs, the 18-hole golf course offers breathtaking views of the South Pacific. Truly a golfer's paradise! 🏌️♂️✨ By the way, I was too busy taking photos of the scenery and forgot to take photos of the Wiedenmann XD8 Terra Spike in action, so it looks like I’ll be going back there soon. #CapeKidnappers #Golf #NewZealand #Wiedenmann #Brandt #Fieldquip #TerraSpike #DeepTineAeration

Last week, I had the opportunity to assist with production of the EPILEPSY FOUNDATION OF MISSOURI AND KANSAS ’ gala in Columbia, Mo. I’m honored to be the creative lead for this Matchbook Marketing Agency client and to work for such an important cause. Special thanks to my account manager Patrick Blair and production specialist Reagan Martin for attending this event with me and helping production go by seamlessly. The EFMK social media team is full of talented and inspiring individuals, and I’m grateful to be working with them this semester.

You might not always be able to control what happens to you, but you can control your actions. Instead of remaining helpless, use these unfortunate events as an opportunity to make a change. A victim mindset will keep you stagnant, but an opportunistic one will catapult you to the future you've always dreamed of. It takes time to shift your perspective, so take it day by day. You'll get there! #Leadership #Mindset #Growth #Success

I recently attended the Responsible Decision-Making and Leadership Workshop in November hosted at the McCoy College of Business at Texas State University .The speakers gave great insight and guidance on being a better leader that I can use in my current role and future opportunities. I was able to make a meaningful connection with the panel of speakers and look forward on collaborating with them in the future. Thank you Robert (Bob) Giacalone , Stephanie S. , William Chittenden, Ph.D. , and Elissa Underwood Marek . and of course Wendi J. Fitch Rios and Diego E Vacaflores
